docs.abstract: Political news from today's Times and around the Web, plus a look at what's happening in Washington.
docs.snippet: Political news from today's Times and around the Web, plus a look at what's happening in Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: The negotiations among lawmakers and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo were far less contentious than in previous years, and officials said they hoped to have a budget before Sunday.

headline.seo: Albany Leaders Work on Budget Deal
headline.main: Cuomo and Top Legislators Near Accord on the Budget
headline.print_headline: Cuomo and Top Legislators Near Accord on the Budget

docs.abstract: New York Gov Andrew M Cuomo and legislative leaders are close to deal on a $132.5 billion spending plan for state; plan slightly reduces overall spending while increasing financing for schools, accelerating public works projects and creating a state gaming commission to oversee gambling.
docs.snippet: The negotiations among lawmakers and Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo were far less contentious than in previous years, and officials said they hoped to have a budget before Sunday.

byline.original: By THOMAS KAPLAN and DANNY HAKIM

docs.lead_paragraph: Randy E. Barnett, a Georgetown law professor, has argued long and loud that the requirement to buy health insurance is unconstitutional.

headline.seo: Randy Barnett’s Pet Cause, End of Health Law, Hits Supreme Court
headline.main: Vindication for Challenger of Health Care Law
headline.print_headline: Vindication for Challenger of Health Care Law

docs.abstract: Supreme Court begins to hear arguments challenging the constitutionality of Pres Obama's health care law; many see Randy E Barnett, a passionate libertarian who teaches law at Georgetown University, as a primary force in driving the question of the law's constitutionality from the fringes of academia into the mainstream of American legal debate and onto the Supreme Court's agenda.
docs.snippet: Randy E. Barnett, a Georgetown law professor, has argued long and loud that the requirement to buy health insurance is unconstitutional.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and CHARLIE SAVAGE

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court seems eager to rule on the core of President Obama’s health care reform law, and it should.
docs.abstract: Editorial contends that the Supreme Court should proceed with its constitutional review of the Affordable Care Act, despite claim by some of the law's advocates that the Anti-Injunction Act bars the court from doing so; argues that in the long term, such tactics will only delay putting the law's constitutionality to rest, and endanger its delivery of health care to millions of Americans who are not currently insured.
docs.snippet: The Supreme Court seems eager to rule on the core of President Obama’s health care reform law, and it should.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: State officials and insurance executives are devising alternatives to the coming federal requirement that most Americans buy health insurance.

headline.seo: Awaiting a Ruling on the Health Law Mandate, and Reviewing Alternatives
headline.main: As Health Law Is Contested, Developing a Plan B
headline.print_headline: Awaiting Health Law Ruling, and Preparing Plan B

docs.abstract: State officials and insurance executives are devising alternatives to the coming federal requirement that most Americans buy health insurance; options being discussed include imposing state requirements that people get insurance, penalties for people who delay and automatic coverage enrollment.
docs.snippet: State officials and insurance executives are devising alternatives to the coming federal requirement that most Americans buy health insurance.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama health care law represents another stage in the concentration of power.
docs.abstract: David Brooks Op-Ed column holds that the Affordable Care Act represents yet another stage in America's historical toward centralization; maintains that universal health care is a worthy goal, and it is reasonable for government to insist that all Americans participate in the insurance network that is the payment method for universal coverage, but suggests that Obamacare's mistake is centralizing cost-control in the hands of few regulators, when decentralized competition is the proper way to make it affordable.
docs.snippet: The Obama health care law represents another stage in the concentration of power.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Times reporters offer analysis of the arguments before the Supreme Court challenging the constitutionality of the 2010 health care law.

headline.seo: Audio and Analysis: The Supreme Court’s Health Care Arguments
headline.main: Analysis of the Arguments — The Supreme Court Health Care Challenges

docs.snippet: Times reporters offer analysis of the arguments before the Supreme Court challenging the constitutionality of the 2010 health care law.

docs.lead_paragraph: A New York Times/CBS News poll finds the individual mandate at the heart of opposition to the law.

headline.main: Most Oppose at Least Part of Overhaul, Poll Finds
headline.print_headline: Most Oppose at Least Part of Overhaul, Poll Finds

docs.abstract: New York Times/CBS News poll finds that two-thirds of Americans want the Supreme Court to overturn some or all of the health care law, even though large majorities support a few of its major aspects; at heart of the opposition is the individual mandate requiring Americans to obtain health insurance.
docs.snippet: A New York Times/CBS News poll finds the individual mandate at the heart of opposition to the law.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.contributor: Marjorie Connelly and Marina Stefan contributed reporting.
byline.original: By DALIA SUSSMAN, HELENE COOPER and KATE PHILLIPS

docs.lead_paragraph: At the opening of three days of arguments challenging the constitutionality of the 2010 health care law, the justices heard 90 minutes of arguments from three lawyers about whether they should be hearing the case at all.

headline.main: Supreme Court Health Care Arguments: Day 1 Transcript
